title: A Landsat 8 Yearbook: Earth Images for Everyone

About 100 days before that, NASA launched Landsat 8 from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California on February 11. See more image pairs like this at the Landsat 8 Yearbook website.[/caption] Scientists, land management professionals, and space enthusiasts already know that Landsat 8 is stocked with a 10-year supply of fuel, that it carries two highly sensitive observation instruments operating more precisely than before, and that the USGS now operates Landsat 8 along with older sister Landsat 7.Â  With two Landsat satellites on orbit, the USGS can provide data every eight days for any spot on the Earthâs land masses, supporting water managers, agricultural commodities markets, and scientists around the globe.
